1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:



At our power plants, we handle isobutane and pentane which are considered hazardous flammables by the US EPA. The same properties that make these regulated substances valuable as a working fluid for the power plants also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling these substances to prevent unnecessary human exposure,  to reduce the threat to our own personal health as well as our facility staff personnel, and to reduce the threat to our community. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulations. Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle these regulated substances combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of these facilities and with the safe operating procedures, mechanical integrity program and the training of our personnel. 



Since our operators do not respond to large chemical releases, we have implemented an Emergency Action Plan which includes procedures for handling small releases of hazardous chemicals as required by OSHA under 29 CFR 1910.38.



2.  Facility and regulated substances handled:



The purpose of our operation is to generate electricity by utilizing the geothermal resource as a source of energy.  The property in which the Steamboat power plants are located is approximately nine miles south of Reno, Nevada and includes eight power plants designated as SB1, SB1A, SB2, SB3, Galena 1, Galena 2, Galena 3, and Steamboat Hills. The SB1 and the SB1A power plants are co-located at the northwest corner of the property. The SB1 facility was shut down in 2004, drained of working fluid and partially disassembled.  SB1 is earmarked for decommissioning.  SB1A uses the regulated substance pentane as the working fluid. The SB2 and SB3 power plants (SB2/3) are located in the northeast corner of the property and both use the regulated substance isobutane as the working fluid. Galena 1 is located 0.2 mile

s south of the SB1/SB1A system.  Galena 3 is located a half mile southwest of SB2/3. Galena 1 and Galena 3 are virtually identical to each other, they both utilize Pentane as their motive fluid.  Galena 2 and Steamboat Hills are located 1.5 miles southwest of Galena 1, They both utilize pentane as their motive fluid.  



- Geothermal Energy and Power Plants

Geothermal energy is renewable heat energy from the earth's core. Geothermal reservoirs of hot water and steam are tapped with production wells and the heat from the geothermal resource is converted to electricity. 

At the Steamboat Power Plants:  SB2/3, SB1A, Galena 1 and Galena 3, hot geothermal brine at temperatures of 300?-315? F is pumped from production wells drilled into the geothermal reservoir. The brine is kept under pressure to keep it from flashing to steam as it is piped through the plant to the heat exchangers where the heat is transferred from the brine to a working fluid (isobutane or pentane). The spent geothermal brine is then injected back into the geothermal reservoir keeping the cycle closed. The heat that was transferred to the working fluid causes the fluid to turn into a vapor.  The vapor is piped through the blades of a turbine, spinning the turbine which is connected to a generator and produces electricity. The hot vapor is then piped through air-cooled condenser tubes, transforming it back to a fluid. The fluid is cycled back to the heat exchangers in a closed-loop system and the process starts again.

Galena 2 runs much the same as the lower steamboat plants, but rather than keeping the brine under intense pressure to keep it a liquid, the geothermal fluid coming out of the ground is separated into steam and brine lines.  Galena has a preheater that is heated by hot brine, and a vaporizer that is heated by steam.  After the steam runs through the vaporizer, it condenses into water and then runs through a recuperator where it heats the water going into the preheater.  The spent steam

then mixed into the brine, and then pumped back into the ground at one of our injection wells.

The Steamboat Hills facility or SBH has two turbines, one known as the STG, and the other known as OEC 41.  The STG is a steam flash turbine and OEC 41 is a binary cycle that utilizes Pentane as it's motive fluid. Rather than using steam in the vaporizer and brine in the preheater, the Steamboat hills plant sends all the brine through OEC 41, and the steam through the STG.  The steam coming out of the STG is condensed buy use of a cooling tower. Any water that isn't lost to the atmosphere during condensation is used to condense the working fluid in a water cooled condenser then mixed with the spent brine on OEC 41 and sent back to injection. 



-  SB1 & SB1A Overview

The SB1 and SB1A Power Plants were developed by Steamboat Geothermal, LLC in 1984 and 1987, respectively. The SB1 facility was shut down in 2004, drained of working fluid and partially disassembled.  SB1 is earmarked for decommissioning.   SB1A is only operated during cooler months and does not operate in the summer. It produces approximately 3 megawatts (gross) of electricity during it's operating season. SB1A uses approximately 55,000 pounds of pentane within a closed-loop system.



-  SB2 & SB3 Overview

The SB2/3 power plants were developed by Steamboat Development Corporation in 1992. In February 2004 Ormat Nevada, Inc assumed the operation of these two plants, while retaining the entire operations, maintenance and management staff. Collectively, SB2 and SB3 produce approximately 40 megawatts (gross) of electricity . Together, the plants use about 660,000pounds of isobutane as the working fluid within their closed-loop systems.



-Galena 1 Overview

The Galena 1 facility was developed in 2005 by ORNI 7, LLC. The facility produces approximately 20 MW of electricity. Galena 1 uses 78,000 pounds of pentane as the working fluid in a closed loop system.

veloped in 2006 by Steamboat Hills, LLC. The facility produces approximately 10 MW of electricity.  Galena 2 uses 136,700 pounds of pentane as the working fluid in a closed loop system.



-Galena 3 Overview

The Galena 3 facility was developed by ORNI 14, LLC.  in 2007. The facility produces approximately 20 MW of electricity Galena 3 uses 78,000 pounds of pentane as the working fluid in a closed loop system.



-Steamboat Hills Overview

The Steamboat Hills facility was developed in 1987 by Caithness Power L.L.C. originally the plan consisted of a single steam powered turbine.  The facility was purchased by Steamboat Hills, LLC in 2004 and in 2006 an Ormat bottoming unit was installed that utilizes the hot brine that is unable to run through the steam turbine. 3.  General accidental release prevention program and specific prevention steps:

The Accidental Release Prevention Program focuses primarily upon the proper training and actions of our operators as outlined by OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM), EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP), and NDEP's Chemical Accident Prevention Program (CAPP). The Training Program, Standard Operating Procedures, Incident Investigation Program, and Management of Change Program ensure that the operator is aware of all potential hazards as well as the measures to mitigate them. 



The Preventive Maintenance and Mechanical Integrity Program are essential in maintaining the integrity of the equipment. Monthly emission inspections are performed to detect leaks at all valve packing and piping flanges, and the proper operation of equipment also play a critical role in our prevention program.

In addition the Accidental Release Prevention Program relies upon safeguards inherent to the design of the power plant. Such safeguards include gas sensors and alarms, relief valves, manual an

d automatic shut-offs, interlocks, vents, and check valves. 

In the event of a fire, the plants are equipped with a sprinkler system, deluge system, fire monitors and hydrants. The operating staff are also trained in the Emergency Action Plan and evacuation procedures.



4.  Five Year Incident History:

We have had no accidental isobutane or pentane releases in the last five years that resulted in deaths, injuries, property damage, or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering-in-place.



5.  Planned changes to improve safety:

Our plants have been operating safely for many years, we will continue to ensure extensive training is provided to are operators as they are essential to plant safety.  A process Hazard analysis is performed on each plant a minimum of every five years or as needed due to a process change.
